VI. ILLUSTRATION IN DEPTH (Excerpt from television lesson shown)
ENGLISH class (LITERATURE) 10th grade (Utilization in accelerated group)
Unit: "Are Things Really What They Seem?" (Emphasis on the multilevel approach
to appreciation)
To accept things at their face value frequently is to deprive ourselves of an
abundance of truth and gratification. Lewis Carroll*s fantasies, Alice in
Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass are used as bases of study (l) to
illustrate how the process of investigation can enlarge meaning and essence
in the humanities as well as in science, and (2) to suggest significant
relationships among the various areas of human activity which may pass un¬
noticed by the superficial student.
A. EXCERPT: UTTER PART OF TELEVISION LESSON
Highlights from the personality and pursuits of the Reverend Charles Lutwidge
Dodgson, young Oxford Don and Mathematical Lecturer of Christ Church...
ending with a river picnic (on July 4, 1862) with the three daughters of Oxford
Dean Liddell.. .and the story-telling session in the shadow of a hayrick.. .the
story revealed as a continuing narrative destined to become "Alice in Wonder¬
land." Television teacher has touched on the puzzles and riddles which were
so much a part of his relationship with Alice Liddell and other children. The
lesson is left with an open end, with the television teacher raising questions
about the story, its nature and essence. Is it just an amusing story for children?
Does a mathematician and logician and teacher Him off those areas of his mind
and self when he is dealing with children? Why would he tell a story
like this to three little girls? is it a "teaching" story? If so, what is he
trying to teach? Why would a logician tell such an illogical story?
B. PREPARATION: The classroom teacher gives the two fantasies of Lewis Carroll
as a reading assignment. Portions of the stories are read aloud
in class. With the whole class the teacher discusses the
students1 reactions to the stories now...there reactions to the
stories when they were experienced by the students as younger
children. The discussion touches on the levels of appeal...
the rhythms and word sounds., .the impact of character and
scene.. .the outlines of the plot.. .the desire for meaning
equated with the freedom to fantasize. The class discusses the
nature of fantasy.. .the meaning of "logical" and "illogical"
and the relationship of these concepts to fantasy and to reality.
The class discusses differeng approaches to characterization,
as portraits of individuals, as symbols of groups or ideas.
